title: What are some songs similar to Glory Box by Portishead? - Quora

response.answer_text: What could be more similar to “Glory Box” than a song that basically uses the same chord sequence? It sounds the same to me, at least, but I’m a drummer, what do I know about chord sequences? Anyway, here’s Sylvia Howard with “I Wanna Go Somewhere (Close Ur Eyes)” from the soundtrack of Ni pour, ni contre (bien au contraire) (2003) by Cédric Klapisch. (Mediocre film, though, rather watch his Auberge espagnole trilogy instead.)  Sylvia Howard: “I Wanna Go Somewhere (Close Ur Eyes)” (2003)  If that wasn’t obscure enough, I’ve got something even rarer for you. Hipkiss (not to be confused with Stanley Ipkiss from The Mask) with “Love You’re in” from their album debut Bluebird (1997), i.e. around the time that Portishead’s eponymous and unwieldy second album came out. (I had trouble getting my head and heart around that one, let me tell you, but now I love it.) Be that as it may, Hipkiss are the smooth jazzy voice of Catherine Mather and the programming by Andy Campbell — whose guitar work sounds very much like Portishead’s Adrian Utley.  Hipkiss: “Love You’re in” (1997)  Finally, to answer the opening question of what could be more similar to “Glory Box”: why, “Glory Box” itself, of course — but covered by none other than the late, great folk icon John Martyn from his covers album The Church with One Bell (1998). Now, before you press play, I must warn you. This version — where he even cleverly changes the lyrics to tell a male perspective — is so beautiful that you will want to kill yourself afterwards, for nothing else in your life can possibly begin to match this. Ever. You have been warned.  John Martyn: “Glory Box” (1998)

Isaac Hayes’ ‘Ike’s Rap II’ is the source sample of two of the best British tracks of the nineties in Portishead’s ‘Glory Box’ and Tricky’s ‘Hell Around The Corner’. The Portishead version is itself flipped by 18 year-old Ontario singer-songwriter Alessia Cara on ‘Here’ (although it interpolates the original’s intro), basically an opportunity for Cara to show off her vocal style and establish herself on the side of the anti-social introverted teen who doesn’t like parties. Alessia Cara has been doing covers on Youtube, as is the now well-worn path. She signed to Def Jam earlier this year and ‘Here’, produced by Pop & Oak provides an augmented and impressive intro to what is to come Alessia Cara - Here (Lyric Video) source: http://nialler9.com/alessia-cara-flips-portisheads-glory-box/
